ImageData.LabelName: Primary tumor is larger than 5 cm but not larger than 7 cm
Membrane covering the lung or chest wall
Cancer in lymph nodes in lung or near bronchus

OriginalSource.Creator: Terese Winslow
OriginalSource.Comment: Faded out shoulder bones and arm bones
Diversity updates - added Asian features to figure
Added a spot of cancer to the nerve that controls the diaphragm

Removed the large cancer spot in the upper right side of the figure; removed the cancer spot behind the lymph nodes that have cancer in them; and added the letter “a” to the cancer spot in the lower part of the lung where the shaded area from the inset comes in.

Removed the letter “a” from the lymph nodes in the main figure; removed the letter “b” from the cancer spot in the main figure; added “a” to the large inset on the left and changed the label to say “Primary tumor is larger…7 cm”; and changed the letter “c” to “b”, “d” to “c”, “e” to “d”, and “f” to “e”.
Revisions made to image per AJCC 8th edition staging

Diagnoses.Diagnosis: stage IIIA non-small cell lung cancer

ContentDescriptions.ContentDescription: Stage IIIA lung cancer (2); drawing shows (a) a primary tumor (larger than 5 cm but not larger than 7 cm) in the left lung and cancer in lymph nodes in the lung or near the bronchus on the same side of the chest as the primary tumor. Also shown is (b) separate tumors in the same lobe of the lung as the primary tumor and cancer that has spread to (c) the chest wall and the membranes covering the lung and chest wall (top right inset); (d) the nerve that controls the diaphragm; and (e) the sac around the heart (bottom right inset). The trachea, left main bronchus, diaphragm, heart, and a rib (top right inset) are also shown.

Stage IIIA lung cancer (2); drawing shows (a) a primary tumor (larger than 5 cm but not larger than 7 cm) in the left lung and cancer in lymph nodes in the lung or near the bronchus on the same side of the chest as the primary tumor. Also shown is (b) separate tumors in the same lobe of the lung as the primary tumor and cancer that has spread to (c) the chest wall and the membranes covering the lung and chest wall (top right inset); (d) the nerve that controls the diaphragm; and (e) the sac around the heart (bottom right inset). The trachea, left main bronchus, diaphragm, heart, and a rib (top right inset) are also shown.

Captions.MediaCaption: Stage IIIA lung cancer (2). Cancer has spread to lymph nodes on the same side of the chest as the primary tumor. The lymph nodes with cancer are in the lung or near the bronchus. Also, one or more of the following is found: (a) the tumor is larger than 5 centimeters but not larger than 7 centimeters; and/or (b) there are one or more separate tumors in the same lobe of the lung as the primary tumor; and/or cancer has spread to any of the following: (c) the chest wall and/or the membrane that lines the inside of the chest wall, (d) the nerve that controls the diaphragm, and/or (e) the outer layer of tissue of the sac around the heart.

Stage IIIA lung cancer (2). Cancer has spread to lymph nodes on the same side of the chest as the primary tumor. The lymph nodes with cancer are in the lung or near the bronchus. Also, one or more of the following is found: (a) the tumor is larger than 5 centimeters but not larger than 7 centimeters; and/or (b) there are one or more separate tumors in the same lobe of the lung as the primary tumor; and/or cancer has spread to any of the following: (c) the chest wall and/or the membrane that lines the inside of the chest wall, (d) the nerve that controls the diaphragm, and/or (e) the outer layer of tissue of the sac around the heart.
